alert.note: Alert for Eastern, Central El Paso County; Rio Grande Valley of Eastern El Paso, Western Hudspeth Counties; Rio Grande Valley of Eastern Hudspeth County; Western El Paso County (Texas) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS El Paso (Southern New Mexico and extreme Western Texas)
info.headline: Excessive Heat Warning issued June 22 at 2:47PM CDT until June 27 at 1:00AM CDT by NWS El Paso
info.description: ...HEAT ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL MIDNIGHT MDT SATURDAY NIGHT... ...EXCESSIVE HEAT WARNING IN EFFECT FROM MIDNIGHT SATURDAY NIGHT TO MIDNIGHT MDT MONDAY NIGHT... * WHAT...Hot conditions with afternoon high temperatures 105 to 108 degrees for Friday and Saturday. Then dangerously hot conditions for Sunday and Monday with high temperatures of 108 to 110. Morning low temperatures remaining warm in the upper 70s to lower 80s. * WHERE...Much of El Paso county and Rio Grande Valley of Eastern Hudspeth County. * WHEN...For the Heat Advisory, until midnight MDT Saturday night. For the Excessive Heat Warning, from midnight Saturday night to midnight MDT Monday night. * IMPACTS...Extreme heat will significantly increase the potential for heat related illnesses, particularly for those working or participating in outdoor activities. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Heat products will likely be extended through the middle of next week due to prolonged period of hot temperatures.
info.instruction: Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room, stay out of the sun, and check up on relatives and neighbors. Young children and pets should never be left unattended in vehicles under any circumstances. Take extra precautions if you work or spend time outside. When possible reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat stroke. Wear lightweight and loose fitting clothing when possible. To reduce risk during outdoor work, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration recommends scheduling frequent rest breaks in shaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone overcome by heat should be moved to a cool and shaded location. Heat stroke is an emergency! Call 9 1 1.
